ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Spectrum splitting using multi-layer dielectric meta-surfaces for efficient solar energy harvesting

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We designed a high-efficiency dispersive mirror based on multi-layer dielectric meta-surfaces. By replacing the secondary mirror of a dome solar concentrator with this dispersive mirror, the solar concentrator can be converted into a spectrum-splitting photovoltaic system with higher energy harvesting efficiency and potentially lower cost. The meta-surfaces are consisted of high-index contrast gratings (HCG). The structures and parameters of the dispersive mirror (i.e. stacked HCG) are optimized based on finite-difference time-domain and rigorous coupled-wave analysis method. Our numerical study shows that the dispersive mirror can direct light with different wavelengths into different angles in the entire solar spectrum, maintaining very low energy loss. Our approach will not only improve the energy harvesting efficiency, but also lower the cost by using single junction cells instead of multi-layer tandem solar cells. Moreover, this approach has the minimal disruption to the existing solar concentrator infrastructures.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: There have been huge progresses on solar cell efficiencies in recent years [1]. One principal reason for the limited efficiency is the broad solar spectrum. Single p–n junction solar cell can only convert incident photons with energy larger than its band gap, and the extra energy beyond the band gap is dissipated as heat, transferring only part of the solar power into electricity [2]. To improve the utilization of the entire solar spectrum, multi-layer tandem solar cells have been developed [3], in which spectrum splitting is realized by the selective light absorption in each layer. However, the vertical integration of multiple junctions is limited by various issues, including material compatibility, current matching between junctions, transparency loss, resistive loss, etc. In practice, only up to three junctions are typically integrated with the highest reported efficiency of 45 % under concentrated sunlight [4], which is far less than the theoretical limit of 68 % for the infinite-junction cell under unconcentrated sunlight and 86 % under concentrated sunlight. Meanwhile, the parallel version of spectrum splitting was reported [5]. Compared to multi-layer tandem solar cells, parallel spectrum splitting places fewer restrictions on material selection and the number of junctions. To date, the realizations of parallel spectrum splitting have been based on optical filters and geometrical optics [6–11]. Several issues, including their incompatibility with existing solar cell infrastructures, bulky setups, and high packaging cost, greatly limit their industry utilization. Therefore, a parallel spectrum splitting technology with a minimal disruption to the existing solar photovoltaic infrastructures is highly desirable.

Recently, great progresses have been made in optical metamaterials sand metasurfaces [12, 13]. Metamaterials are basically artificial materials which are consisted of nanostructures, and their unique optical properties come from the optical resonant effects of those nanostructure. Metasurfaces are 2-D metamaterials, whose optical properties also come from the nanostructures on the surface. Metasurfaces focus on controlling light propagation using the phase discontinuity generated in the metasurface instead of the bulk optical properties [12]. However, until now, the implementations of metasurfaces have been primarily based on metallic antenna array. Due to the intrinsic material loss associated with metal at visible and shorter wavelength, this type of metasurfaces has only been demonstrated at IR and longer wavelengths. The majority energy of sun light is in visible and UV ranges, so metallic antenna based metasurfaces cannot be used to implement spectrum splitting for solar energy harvesting.

Dielectric meta-surfaces based on high-index-contrast sub-wavelength gratings (HCG) have been developed [14]. In such structure, broadband reflection was observed both theoretically and experimentally [14–16]. So far, periodical HCG has been used as the reflective optics to replace the dielectric mirrors in vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers (VCSEL) [17, 18]. In addition, the phase of reflected wavefronts can be controlled by chirping the HCG. In practice, the chirped HCG has been shown to steer wavefronts and thus to mimic a number of reflective optics including concave mirrors and prisms [19–21]. However, most of the applications can only operate in a restricted range of wavelengths. Both metallic meta-surfaces and dielectric meta-surfaces (HCG-based structure) capable of steering the entire solar spectrum have never been reported before.

In this paper, we provide numerical study results for developing planar dispersive mirrors with multi-layer HCG structures, which have the ability to steer the light beams of the entire solar spectrum. Furthermore, we propose a parallel spectrum splitting system with the integration of our dispersive mirror, which can reflect and guide incident beam to different directions according to different wavelengths. Our design for the dispersive mirror relies on abundant materials and simple planar structures which can be fabricated at a low cost using nanoimprint lithography (NIL) [22]. Moreover, the proposed system features an easy integration with existing concentrator photovoltaic (CPV) setups. Therefore, our spectrum splitting solution with HCG-based dispersive mirrors has the potential to be accepted widely by the industry and to achieve solar energy harvesting with higher efficiency at a lower cost.

Section1.Heading: Design of dispersive mirror structure
Section1.Para:
In our design, the dispersive mirror (Fig. 1) is built with a multi-layer structure, in which several sub-wavelength 2-D HCG layers are stacked vertically. First, its multi-layer structure can provide good total reflection to cover the entire solar spectrum to minimize the optical loss. Each layer is built with similar structure with scaled-up grating pitches from the first layer to the last layer. Therefore, the layers closer to the surface operate in shorter wavelength range while the ones at the bottom operate in longer wavelengths. The property of HCG enables that each layer only reflects the light with the wavelength in its reflection band and lets higher-wavelength components pass through with negligible loss. The sub-wavelength dimension also prevents energy loss in higher order diffractions. Second, each layer is chirped differently to direct each band to different angles. Last, the 2-D structure is polarization independent which is important for reflective optics in solar concentrators

The physics behind the sub-wavelength HCG have been studied in various ways [15, 17, 23, 24], which all explained the broad-band reflection behavior of unchirped HCG. That exotic nature of HCG is one of the foundations to our dispersive mirror design, in which multiple layers of HCG are stacked. Each of HCG layers shows similar broad-band reflection at different central wavelengths and by combining all the reflection bands, the device can provide good reflection in a broad wavelength range.

Other than broad-band reflection, the localized phase controlling ability of HCG is also indispensable for our design, so that the reflection direction in each HCG layer can be well controlled and the overall reflectance will not degrade too much due to chirping. However, this part of physics has not been studied thoroughly.

To investigate that, We compared HCG with the guided-mode resonance grating (GMR) [25]. In contrary to GMR, which has less contrast in refractive index, HCG is composed of materials with high refractive index contrast and a structure that helps to maximize the effect of that. For example, in GMR, between the low-index substrate and high-index grating bars, there exists a waveguide layer. In HCG, however, the grating bars directly touch substrate, leaving no consecutive waveguide layer in between. Both HCG and GMR are perturbations to the lateral guided mode wave. For HCG, the perturbation is stronger so the guided mode is leakier and thus more localized compared to that in GMR. Therefore, in some sense, each grating in HCG can be treated as a separate resonator, which can radiate in both reflection and transmission directions. When those modes interfere destructively in the transmitting surface by designing the parameters for HCG, high reflection can be achieved.

As shown in Fig. 2, a plane wave optical source only excites three gratings in both HCG and GMR. Both the magnitude of electric field and poynting vector distribution are presented. The grating materials for both HCG and GMR (including waveguide layer) are TiO

and the substrates for both are fused silica. In HCG, the resonances are well confined within three gratings where the plane wave enters, and the light propagates very little laterally. In GMR, however, due to the existence of waveguide layer, there are obvious resonances in the both gratings and waveguide layer nearby. The stronger resonances and less propagation lengths in HCG compared to those in GMR is a proof that guided mode is leakier in HCG. Therefore, the field distribution shown in Fig. 2 agrees with our previous physical analysis. The difference in leaky modes for GMR and HCG is a fundamental reason for different features in reflection.

For low-index grating such as GMR, the longer propagation length of guided modes restricts that narrowband reflection can only be attained with optimal parameters and the reflection comes from global periodicity. If the periodicity is disrupted by chirping, the reflection will be affected seriously. On the contrary, with a localization of guided modes in the HCG, even after chirping, it is possible to achieve a good broadband reflection for each layer in the dispersive mirror with optimal parameters. The design rational is closer to meta-surfaces than regular GMR gratings.

Section1.Heading: Numerical design and optimization
Section1.Para:
In every layer of HCG-based dispersive mirror, the material for substrates is fused silica. As discussed previously, grating bars with high-index materials are necessary. In order to provide a benchmark to filter grating materials, finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) [26] and rigorous coupled-wave analysis (RCWA) [27] methods were adopted to optimize the HCG structures with different index of refraction (Fig. 3). The higher is the refractive index, the broader is the reflection band. When refractive index is equal or lower than 2, narrow-band reflection occurs during the optimization, because the index contrast is not enough for leaky guided modes in HCG and the gratings behave like diffractive grating or GMR rather than HCG. To obtain reasonable reflection band for simple HCG structure, an index of refraction larger than 2.5 is favorable. Meanwhile, the materials should not be lossy, so the imaginary index of refraction should be close to zero in the operating wavelength range.

T-shape HCG, instead of simple HCG structure, is employed in the first layer to solve the issue. With a T-shape structure, good reflection band can be achieved even though the index of material is lower than favorable value in the benchmark (Fig. 4). Compared to simple HCG, T-shape structure creates more contacting area for grating bars with the ambient low-index media. Therefore, the index contrast is further improved by the physical structure when the high-refractive-index material is hard to obtain.

Therefore, the first layer is designed with the T-shape HCG structure while all five subsequent layers have simple HCG structures. Compared to T-shape, simple HCG structure is easier to fabricate and less fragile, so we choose to incorporate the T-shape positive HCG only when necessary (in layer 1 only). After detailed FDTD and RCWA numerical optimization and parameter tradeoff, the reflection curves for all six layers are shown in Fig. 5. Because each layer is 2-D HCG, the reflection performance is polarization independent. All six-layer combined can provide larger than 95 % reflection over the entire solar spectrum.

As shown in Fig. 1, the ability to split the reflected spectrum is realized by chirping the stacked HCG. Chirping the periodic HCG to control the reflected wavefronts is physically attainable due to the strong localization of guided mode. As shown in Fig. 6, HCG is chirped by changing the parameters locally following the chirping trajectory. The gradual change of parameters will incur different phase shifts on locally reflected wavefront and the reflected local waves with different phase will behave as if the reflected light is tilted by it. The phase difference of 2 between the ending of one chirping period and the beginning of the next one is preferred. In this way, the wavefronts of each chirping period can be connected smoothly. The tilting angles can be controlled by the width of each chirping period.

Since 2-D structures have been incorporated, we can either chirp the grating so that all the light separates along the same axis (Fig. 7a) or we can chirp the 2-D structure in orthogonal directions for separation in all directions (Fig. 7b). In our study, we also noticed that the chirped grating will incur phase shifts to transmitted part, which is designed to be reflected by next layers; therefore, the wavefront will be distorted. However, we can further adjust the chirping setup for next layers to compensate the wavefront distortion of the transmitted light.

Section1.Heading: Implementation
Section1.Para:
One possible implementation is shown in Fig. 8, which is very similar to a conventional solar concentrator [28], except that we replace the reflective mirror in the solar concentrator with the dispersive mirror. In the schematic, the sun light is first reflected by the dish-like concentrator and shines on the reflective dispersive mirror. The beam is then reflected into different angle that is determined by the wavelength of the components. The proof-of-principle design of dispersive mirror in this implementation is provided in the paper, which has the ability to break the spectrum into several pieces and reflect to different direction. Such exotic characterization is realized by the special nano-structures (multi-layer sub-wavelength HCGs) inside the dispersive element.

Section1.Heading: Discussion and conclusion
Section1.Para: In this paper, we provided the numerical evidence to obtain the proof-of-principle design of a dispersive mirror consists of multi-layer dielectric meta-surfaces based on stacked chirped HCG. To illustrate the basic concept, our numerical studies shown above were based on normal incident plane wave, which is a first-order approximation from real solar light for the convenience of numerical study. The parameters can be further adjusted to attain optimal reflection under real solar incidence.

Furthermore, we presented a spectrum splitting setup by replacing the reflective mirror in a conventional solar concentrator with the dispersive mirror. In our proposed system, the incoming light is not always normal incident plane wave, especially around the edges of the dispersive mirrors. The aberration of wavefronts from the solar concentrator needs to be compensated by tuning the parameters of gratings in our dispersive mirror. The reflection phase shift can be designed to match the aberration from the concentrator by setting the parameters (phase shift) of the gratings locally.

To sum up, this HCG-based dispersive mirror and the spectrum splitting approach has the minimum disruption to the existing solar concentrator infrastructure, so it has the potential to be accepted by the industry and to greatly enhance solar energy harvesting efficiency and lower the cost.
